title: Kubernetes Complexity Cascade
context: Organization with 10-50 engineers. The monolith is showing scaling pain. Someone proposes Kubernetes. The pitch sounds right: better scaling, deployment flexibility, industry-standard infrastructure. What they don't model is the cascade that follows. The decision to adopt K8s triggers a chain of second-order effects that compound over 12-24 months. Suddenly you need Helm for packaging, Istio for service mesh, ArgoCD for GitOps, Prometheus for monitoring. Your infra team doubles. Onboarding goes from 2 weeks to 6. Debugging a production issue now means tracing through pods, services, ingress controllers, and network policies instead of reading a stack trace.
hypothesis: Kubernetes will give us better scaling, deployment flexibility, and industry-standard infrastructure.

effects.label: K8s alone is insufficient — tooling sprawl

children.label: Network issues masquerade as app issues

dontIf: You don't have genuine multi-region requirements
Your scaling problems are actually database problems
ifYouMust: Start with managed K8s (EKS/GKE/AKS), never self-hosted
